Name: Milky Way
Description: You win the game by making it to planet Earth-- where your Milky Way Child will renew his or her Milky Way power and assist the Parentals in defeating the Evil Agents of the four supreme Galaxies.  (Quoted from Instructions.)

Name: Roosevelt at San Juan
Description: Children's trivia game designed to teach the facts of the Spanish-American war and Teddy Roosevelt's thoughts on it.  Sample questions: Where did the Rough Riders land in Cuba?  What should New York thank Roosevelt for?

Name: Game of the Little Volunteer
Description: Children's game in which players start as a little drummer boy and rise to the rank of Commander-in-Chief. Grisly images of bloodshed, apparently not troubling to parents of the times cover the gameboard.

Name: Boxer Rebellion
Description: Wargame depicting the Boxer Rebellion. Unusual Setting and Rules. Players are various foreign armies racing each other to the Legation neighborhood in the middle of Hong Kong. Players fight Chinese Army and Rebel Forces on the way there, who are only revealed by scouting. Counters and Map are provided.

Name: Game of Napoleon: The Little Corporal
Description: Players move around a board which teaches the life story of Napoleon, starting with his birth in Corsica through his exile on St. Helena.  I suppose the goal is to NOT finish first.

Name: Game of War at Sea or "Don't Give Up the Ship"
Description:
Published at the time of the Spanish-American War, players move their ships across a checkerboard pattern covering the Gulf of Mexico, Carribean, the coast of Central America, and the U.S. Atlantic seaboard.  The goal is to sweep the opponent's navy from the sea.

Game comes with 12 Battleships and 12 Torpedo Boats.

Name: The Game of Telegraph Boy or Merit Rewarded
Description: Similar to other McLoughlin Bros. games of this period, players start out in a menial job, then work their way up through hard work and virtue, and become President at game end.

Name: Colonial Empires
Description: Card game simulation of European Colonization and expansion circa 1600-1850. 10 different Nations to Choose from, each with its own special ability. 10 Colonial Regions to discover and exploit. Develop Home Industries. Wage war at home and in foreign lands. Amass the largest Fortune to win. Simple card play.

Name: I Love Chautauqua
Description: This is a Monopoly-style game using the theme of Jamestown, New York (USA) and the surrounding Chautauqua County.  The various properties and spaces on the board reflect businesses, landmarks, and locations in Jamestown and Chautauqua County.  This game also incorporates the history of the area, as the event cards in the game contain various historical anecdotes.

Name: Edmontonopoly
Description:
From the box:

It's EdmontonOpoly... the most exciting board game of the year! Budding tycoons can now buy and sell the most established business, landmarks, tourist attractions and restaurants in Edmonton with a simple roll of the dice in this fun filled - exciting new board game!

Name: Pimp City
Description:
Pimp City is the party game where you’re the pimp and your objective is to move your whore around the board, make the most money, and become the New Pimp Daddy!

Pimp City has Cat Fights, Trick Ownership, Truth or Dare options, Neighborhood Watch Cards, Slammer Time, Sugar Daddies, Big Tippers, The Alley, and even Revenge!

Home Page: http://www.pimpcitythegame.com/

Name: The Howard Hughes Game
Description:
In The Howard Hughes Game players move via die roll on a two-dimensional grid, drawing or trading cards when they land on the appropriate spaces. The goal is to get cards of the different types (Luck, Inheritance, and Corporate Know-How) for each of the eight phases of Hughes' life (as defined by the game) in turn. The phases are entered via "doors" on the board and the cards are turned in for money, which is tracked on a small board for each player. In true Hughes style, players may purchase injunctions to prevent movement through certain areas of the board. The object is to amass $2.5 billion dollars, the publisher's estimate of Hughes' fortune at the time.

In addition to the rules, the "Study Guide" booklet contains 21 pages of material on the life and investments of Howard Hughes and an extensive bibliography.

Although the name "Urban Systems" does not appear on the game, this is presumably the game in the case Rosemont Enterprises, Inc. v. Urban Systems, Inc. (72 Misc.2d 788, 789-90, 340 N.Y.S.2d 144, 145-46 [Sup.Ct.], modified, 42
App.Div.2d 544, 345 N.Y.S.2d 17 [App.Div.1973]). This case resulted in a judgement for Hughes against the game publisher, requiring them to withdraw the game from sale.

Name: World of Warcraft: The Boardgame – BlizzCon Epic Armor Pack
Description:
World of WarCraft: the Board Game Epic Armor Sets Mini-Expansion! Special custom sets of armor for each of the nine classes, straight out of World of Warcraft: The Boardgame! Oh, and a Murloc Suit, because who doesn't want a Murloc Suit?

Expands:

    World of Warcraft: The Boardgame

Name: "Swish" Basketball Game
Description: Comes with a spinner, and a punch out basketball. The board is 13 1/2 by 10 1/2 inches and depicts basketball players from a red jerseyed team and a blue jerseyed team. Instructions are on the back of the board. Family sports game published sometime in the 1950s by Whitman.

Name: Monsoon Seas: Naval Warfare in the South Atlantic and Indian Oceans, 1777-1783
Description:
The British Navy at bay - part two

Clash of Arms Games continues to explore warfare in the age of the fighting sail with Monsoon Seas. Monsoon Seas is Volume III of Mark Campbell's naval warfare Close Action series.

This set of special rules and scenarios covers mainly the 1777-1783 campaigns of French Admiral Pierre-Andre de Suffren and his battles with the Royal Navy in the South Atlantic and Indian Ocean (seventeen scenarios). The first three scenarios concern the Spanish-Portuguese War of 1776-1777 over what would become Uruguay.

20+ Scenarios explore the dramatic engagements and set piece battles of: Sadras, Providien, Negapatam, Trincomalee, Cuddalore and more.

This set of specific rules (72 pages), scenarios and historical commentary is a worthy successor to her highly acclaimed sister games Close Action: The Age of Fighting Sail Vol. 1 and Rebel Seas: The British Navy at Bay Part I.

(source: Clash fo Arms website and user's description))
Families: Series: Close Action (Clash of Arms Games)

Name: Triumph of Chaos Comrades Guide
Description: 80 Page Triumph of Chaos Comrades' Guide including 88 additional counters (armies, leaders, variants, etc), variants, strategy articles, play tips, historic analysis (American Foreign Legion, Kosciuszko Air Squadron, Ukrainian Galician Army and the insurgent army of anarchist Nestor Makhno), designer comments, survey of Russian Civil War games, many playaids and much more.

Name: Triple Crown
Description:
Each player uses pieces of a different colour.

On each of his turns a player rolls four dice. The value of one of the dice is taken as the ROW NUMBER. Two other dice together are the COLUMN number. The left over die is the scoring die. The cross section between ROW and COLUMN must be  vacant to set the scoring die. Now if there are more Tiles adjacent to the new one (regardless of the colour) the you score. If there are tiles of your colour you´ll get some bonuses.

The game ends, when all players can not place one legal legal tile anymore. Player with highest score wins

Name: Big Brother Truth or Dare
Description:
Big Brother Truth or Dare is an adult boardgame where players take turns answering opponents truth or dare cards.

The Truth or Dare cards contain more than 1,500 questions and each question has a corresponding level of naughtiness of either Prude, Rude or Lewd. Players progress around the board by moving the number of spaces indicated on each card - 1 for Prude, 2 for Rude and 3 for Lewd.

The winner is the first person to cross the finish line.

Dares range from "Play air guitar" through to "Snog another player", whilst questions include "When was the last time you were blindfolded?" and "Describe a love triangle you’ve been involved in."

Name: Nochnoj Dozor
Description:
This Russian card game is based on the novel and the film (2004) with the same name, also known as Night Watch.

The series is continued with Dnevnoj Dozor (Day Watch) with another mechanics.

Name: Tannhäuser: Operation Novgorod
Description:
Deep in their secret Siberian bases, the Russian Scientific Security Committee has assembled a weapon defying all known physical laws, Project Code Name: S.V.A.R.O.G.
During the project’s final testing phase, the laboratory super-generator suddenly exploded. Was it an overload? A commando attack? The awakening of ancient Slavic deities?

You can be a part of this exciting adventure in the upcoming TannhÃ¤user supplement Operation Novgorod.

Incarnate the role of Zor’Ka... 
Discover the Religious Commissar Irena Kravchenko... 
Stalk the ruins of an Ultra Top Secret Russian research center... 
Master the talents of Major Volkov, a Hero decorated by the people with the prestigious Gold Star...

Collect new Equipment, Packs, and Objectives for the Union and the Reich.  Challenge your opponents with new Game Modes and surprising rule variants.  Get your fill of action, heroics, strategy, and suspense.

Find all this and more in Operation Novgorod!

Name: Tannhäuser: Wolf
Description:
Wolfgang Otto Ludwig Friedrich, alias Wolf, is a mercenary with no loyalty, no scruples, and no mercy. Willing to work for either the Reich or the Union if the price is right, Wolf is a consummate professional and a valuable asset to either side. The Wolf single miniature pack comes with everything you need to include Wolf in your TannhÃ¤user game: one pre-painted Wolf figurine, character sheet, game tokens, and a rulebook including a special bonus scenario featuring Wolf.

Wolf was originally a special promotional single miniature pack that was made available to all customers who preordered TannhÃ¤user either directly from Fantasy Flight's GenCon2007 booth or from the official FFG online store or participating brick-and-mortar retailers before August 25th, '07.

Name: Sexual Dilemmas
Description:
Sexual Dilemmas is not just a fun game to play.  It also provides for stimulating conversation and frank discussion that may lead you to know everything you never wanted to know about your freinds, neighbors and relatives.  Sample questions:

    HIS: Your 15 year-old daughter asks if you have been sleeping with the woman you are dating.  If so do you tell her?
    HERS: Your neighbors have invited you to a hot tub party.  Some of the people you know, some you don't.  You are the only one who has brought a suit.  Will you take off your clothes?

Name: Silly Stix
Description:
A clever little memory game where children drop brightly colored rods of varying lengths down hollow blocks of varying depths. The first player to line up three level heads in a row wins the game! When the rods are dropped, will they fall to the bottom of the block or stop somewhere in between? Switch the blocks and heads around each time you play to encourage memory development and essential silly skills!

Contents:
9 wooden blocks of various depths, 2 rod holders, 2 sets of 9 colored rods of various lengths, instructions.

Name: King for a Day
Description:
Players take the part of competing nobles trying to become king.

Players bid for special abilities, collect resource cards and gold and also build structures to generate gold and more power.

At the end, the player with the most Power wins.

Home Page: http://www.fairplaygames.com/newworldgames/bnw/3%204%205.html

Name: Bumpback
Description: In Bumpback your goal is to move all of your pawns from the start space around the board to the finish space before your opponent. The game can be played with anywhere from 2 to 8 pawns per player. If you wish to play a shorter game you may choose fewer pawns to start with. If you wish to play a longer game you can start with more pawns. Players take turns rolling and moving their pawns around the board. The game includes a Bumpback die that can be rolled when you land on a space that is occupied by another player. The Bumpback die sends pawns back to their start position. Each space has six dots on it and the number rolled on the Bumpback die applies to any pawn resting on that numbered dot. The game can get very exciting with 4 players and 32 pawns on the board.

Name: Royal Flush
Description: The "exciting action game of Poker Cubes".  The game plays like Yahtzee, but instead of using normal dice you use cubes with card symbols on them.  The top section of the score card has each card symbol on the dice, Ace, Nine, Ten, Jack, Queen, and King.  Each is assigned a value 1 to 6. You score the number assigned times the number of dice you roll of that type.  Just like Yahtzee you get a bonus if you score high enough in the top section.  In the bottom section you attempt to get a straight, full house, royal flush, etc..

Name: Oneonta Whist
Description:
This is a cardgame, originally developed as a solitaire trick-taking game.  It is derived from Spades and Whist.

Rules for cooperative play:
Go around, and everyone makes their bids. The object is for the group to collectively (every person in their group) to meet their bids. Players determine at the start how much communication is allowed between players. Everyone plays as one team. The object is to get a high score. One could also base scoring around lowest scoring player.

Name: Medieval
Description:
Western Europe, middle of the VIII century. The players take on the role of the growing monastic orders of the time, and their mission is to be first in building a certain number of abbeys across the board. Round after round, the senior abbots of each order rely on the benefits derived from those in power to make their abbeys the most influential political, spiritual or production centers, or all three, as those hardy monks were at the same time those who prayed, those who fought and those who worked.

Game elements:

1 Board   (Showing a map of Western Europe divided in 7 regions)
5 Senior Abbot figures
6 Power cards (King, Baron, Hermit, Abbot, Bishop and Townsman)
6 Brother cards  (Herbolarius, Cook, Secretary, Blacksmith, Goldsmith, Copyist)
10 Action markers (2 in each of the players’ colors)
36 Power tokens (12 of each: Spiritual, Political, and Material)
36 Foundation markers (featuring two or three power symbols) 
50 Abbeys (10 in each of the players’ colors)
84 Buildings (14 of each: Chancellery, Blacksmith shop, Scriptorium, Basilica, Wheat, Wine Cellar.)
102 Good tokens (17 of each: Books, Reliquaries; Letters, Shields; Wine Bottles, loaves of Bread)
50  coins (30 x $5, 20 x $1)
1 Pope figure

Name: TAASEN
Description:
TAASEN
The Game Of Tryslmaistan Chess

A web published game, described as an analogue of Chess (but feeling closer to Checkers in depth).  Played on a triangular board made up of triangles.  Each player has three pieces.  A third set of three pieces (white) is available for use by either play.

On your turn you may move one of your pieces or a white piece.

The objective is to remove your opponent's pieces from the board or immobilize them.  Unlike chess, your pieces push your opponent's (and White's) pieces around into free spaces.  If no space is free, then the pushed piece is removed.

This game was developed after appearing in the web comic "Unicorn Jelly".

The game's home page : http://www.unicornjelly.com/taasen1.html

Name: Bratz Girl Talk
Description:
From the Manufacturer:

The Stylin' Game of Truth or Dare

Want to laugh with your friends? Express your passion for fashion? Do krazy things? Then dare to play BRATZ GIRL TALK.

Sing a song...strut your stuff...tell a tale...and lots more. That's what BRATZ GIRL TALK is all about!

Spin the spinner and see if you'll have to do a funadelic stunt or answer a "tell all" question. Not hip enough to complete the dare? Then you won't score the points for that turn! Be the first to get 25 points and you rule. Ten check out the BRATZ CHAT cards you've collected to see just what your friends really think of you!

Ages 8 and up.

Name: Pegleg Pete's Deck of Royal Rogues
Description: This is a standard deck of 52 playing cards plus 4 extra cards and 2 jokers.  The extra cards are the Serpents of Clubs, diamonds, hearts, and spades.  The deck can be used to play any game you can play with a standard poker deck.  The entire deck has a pirate motif.  All the art is new and original.

Name: Death Dice
Description:
Quoted from the back of the package Copyright 1981 Flying Buffalo Inc.:

Skulls
A game for any number of people
Required:  two "Death Dice", paper and pencil

This game is played in six rounds.  The object is to get the highest score after six rounds.  Each of the two dice has number on five of the six sides, and a skull on the sixth side.

Determine which player goes first by any convenient method.  First player rolls both dice.  If no skulls are showing, the player adds the numbers showing to his score for the round.  He he has the option of rolling again, or passing the dice to the next player.  If he passes the dice, his turn is over, and the score he has rolled so far is "protected."  If he rolls again, he may get more points, but he may also lose all the points he has received so far that round.  A player may continue to roll the dice until he decides to pass them, or until he rolls one or more skulls.  If a player rolls one skull, he loses all the points he has gained that round, and gets a score of zero for the round.  He must then pass the dice to the next player.  If a player rolls two skulls, he loses all the points he as gained that round, and in all previous rounds.  He is completely wiped out, and must start again the next round.  He must pass the dice to the next player.

After all the players have had a chance to roll the dice, draw a line under the scores to signify that the scores above the line are "protected" (i.e., cannot by wiped out the the roll of a single skull).  Note that each player must roll the dice at least once each round.

Subsequent rounds:  In the following rounds, players roll the dice in the order of their score so far.  The player with the highest score at they end of the first round will roll first for the second round.  The player with the second highest score will roll second, and so on.  There is an advantage to rolling last, so we give that position to the player who is losing the worst.  If two players are tied for score, they may roll a dice or flip a coin to determine which must roll first.

At the end of six rounds the player with the highest score wins.  If two players are tied for the highest score, then all players must roll another round.

Hint:  although the odds of rolling a skull on any one roll are always exactly the same as any other roll, the more times you roll in one round, the more points you are rising on any one roll.

Flying Buffalo Inc. P.O. Box 1467 Scottsdale, AZ  85252
Product Number 0204
1981

Name: Home Base Ball Game
Description: Simple children's baseball game from the turn of the last century.  Mechanical bat swings at a small pitched ball with 7 tin fielders which may "field" the ball.

Name: Game of Golf
Description: A simple children's roll and move game in which the goal is to complete six holes of golf.  Good rolls make the ball land in the fairway and make for a quick game.  Poor rolls send the player into the rough, making the path to each hole longer.

Name: Excursion to Coney Island
Description: Similar to the Peter Coddle games, players read about an trip to Coney Island filled with adventure, with players inserting funny phrases either at random or after they've been dealt and players shout them out when appropriate, or perhaps it's funnier when the words are inappropriate.

Name: Game of City Life or the Boys of New York
Description: Very simple game in which players draw cards and play into or take from a community pool.  The real point of the cards is to show the various types of people living in NYC, which was then as it is now, the largest and grandest city in the Union.  Cards vary from the positive to the very negative.

Name: Game of Race Around the World
Description: Simple roll and move game meant to teach geography along with counting.  A simple numbered track is printed on a map of the world.  Players spin to move, hoping to miss hazard spaces.

Name: Game of Trip Round the World
Description: A simple roll and move children's game designed to teach some geography as players spin their way around the globe, hoping to avoid hazard spaces.

Name: Game of Uncle Sam's Mail
Description: Players move around the U.S. by horseback, stagecoach, steamboat, and railroad to deliver their randomly drawn pieces of mail. Each player takes one postman piece. The object of the game is to deliver 6 letters.  The letters are first sorted into piles according to postmarks. Players then take 1 letter from each pile so that 1 letter will have to be delivered to each section of the country. Players either start in New York or San Francisco. The object is to deliver the letters to the various cities to which they are addressed. The game claims to have the best and most practical general railroad map in use.
Families: Theme: Mail / Stamps / The Post Office

Name: Traxs
Description:
The Music Challenge

Ready! Steady! Go!

All you get is 15 seconds to come up with a tune.

A card is flipped over that contains a specific word. Within 15 seconds, the active player has to sing any tune in which the word appears.

Any age, any generation, from Rock ‘n Roll to Rap, TRAXS covers it all!

Name: Question Mark
Description:
The cut to the chase trivia game that can be played in trains, planes, automobiles or at home at the braai (barbecue), or even around the pool.

The first player/team to correctly answer 20 questions is the winner.

So grab your pad & pencil and colour your way to victory.

Question Mark is all about pure knowledge!

Name: Fantasy Island Rails
Description:
A web-published variant of the well-known Empire Builder system by Mayfair Games. This game takes place on an eight piece modular map representing a group of islands.  The area covered is smaller than the usual Empire Builder game and the terrain is extremely limited.  It is limited to only 2-3 players.

The game can be downloaded here:
http://www.zahag.de/MMsKSg/rails/fir/main.html

Name: Het Grote Taalspel Frans
Description:
Het Grote Taalspel Frans ('The big language-learning game French') is a boardgame for Dutch-speaking children and adults, who wants to learn French. The 20-sided dice decides to which region you have to move your pawn. You have to choose a mission in this region. There are 6 missions: figuring - drawing - writing - quiz - translating - speaking. If you're successful in this mission, you become the owner of this region. The player who has 10 regions, wins the game. During the game, you can earn action cards. Those action cards can influence the further game-process.


Het Grote Taalspel Frans is een bordspel voor nederlandstalige kinderen en volwassen die Frans willen leren. Door middel van een dobbelsteen verplaats je je pion naar één van de 20 regio's. In deze regio kies je een opdracht. De opdrachten zijn: Uitbeelden - tekenen - schrijven - quiz - vertalen - spreken. Als je de opdracht juist hebt, dan ben je (mede-)eigenaar van deze regio. Wie eerst 10 regio's bezit, is de winnaar van het spel. Gedurende het spel kan je actiekaarten verdienen die je kunnen helpen of de anderen kunnen dwarsbomen.

Name: Caliphate
Description:
Caliphate focuses on the rise and fall of Islamic civilization in the (approx.) 7th to 12th centuries. It is a game of conquest, trade, diplomacy, and building up your emirate economically, culturally, military, etc. Inspired by historical events, but not a strict historical simulation.

Players represent different Emirates that are rivals for control after Muhammed’s death at the end of his conquests. Each player controls an area on the map, along with a number of army units with which he can battle others and take over more territory.

In addition to combat, there are economic issues to attend to. Emirates produce a number of goods according to the size of area controlled, and players trade surplus commodities with each other to generate earnings. This trade income is combined with taxes to pay the required expenses of maintaining the army and to purchase infrastructure improvements.

Name: Peter Coddle Tells of His Trip to Chicago
Description: Follow up to several Peter Coddle visits New York games from the same period.  Players fill out the story of Peter's travels by filling in the funny phrases they have drawn from the pile.

Name: Bagh Guti
Description:
There is a large and varied class of hunt games, called tiger games, from south east Asia.  They are all played on square boards, and feature one or more tigers against a number of hunters.

Bagh guti is one such game, and it comes from India.  Its antiquity is unknown; western accounts of the game date from 1906.  It is particularly interesting as, unlike many other games of this type, multiple pieces are initially stacked upon a point.
Families: Traditional Games: Alquerque / Fanorona (Indian War Games)

Name: Cursed Earth Game
Description: Game based on the Judge Dredd comic. Mega-city 2 is threatened by a deadly plague and Judge Dredd sets out on dangerous journey through the Cursed Earth to deliver a vaccine. Guide your player - Judge Dredd, "Spikes" Harvey Rotten, Tweak or a nameless judge - from Mega-city 1 to Mega-city 2. During the game, you will spend resources and credits to get through the dangers of the Cursed Earth. The player with the most credits when the game ends is the winner. This game was originally published in the 2000AD comic book issues #75-80.

Name: WirRheinländer
Description:
Explore the fascinating history of the German Rheinland with this trivia game. You don' have to be an eager beaver to win this game - you need skill and luck to be the first to reach the goal with the pawn in your colour. 
However, each colour may be moved by everyone - and there are some traps along the way, so watch out.... 
When reaching special fields a card is drawn. There are two kinds of cards - Knowledge Cards that require you to answer a question concerning the Rheinland and Action Cards that mix up the outcome of the game...

Name: Zahlen Zickzack
Description: Quite simple 'get rid of your cards first' game. Every player gets a pile of cards (Cards are numbered from 1-25, each number is contained 4 times) and draws 4 cards. On your turn you can place cards on one (ore more) of the two upwards (start from 1 or the two downwards piles (start from 25). You can play only cards which are exactly one higher/lower. If you play a card that matches that criteria (even on your discard pile) you can draw another card and continue. Whoever gets rid of his cards first wins.

Name: Drill
Description:
The goal is to collect moving birds of different colours.

Everyone has a player mat with an unique combination of coloured circles to place birds on. To get a bird one will have to roll the three dices to show the same colour. First one to fill the player mat wins.

Name: Hämä hämä häkki
Description:
The game is based on the nursery rhyme "Incy Wincy Spider" (also known as Itsy Bitsy Spider).

Players takes the roles as spiders and build webs to climb and depend on the weather. If it's sunny they can climb up the web but if it rains they are washed down.

Name: Barsaman
Description: Barsaman is a backgammon like game on a circular board. Using three dice each player tries to bear off his pieces using standard, double and triple moves. The dice determine in which ring on the board you are allowed to play. Along the way the opponent's pieces can be blocked or captured. Captured pieces help you finish the game early. Player with the most pieces borne off wins.

Name: Lucy's Race for Fame Trivia game
Description:
Billed as the trivia game about the TV Show, "I Love Lucy" that was created by fans of the show for other fans of the show, this game features over 1,000 trivia questions.

The gameboard depicts a stylized map of New York City with memorable locations highlighted from episodes of the show.  Players compete to answer question correctly to move around the city and be the first to win a television contract with Studio 10 Television Center

Name: Glenn Baker's Rock Academy
Description: This is a music trivia board game from Glenn Baker, who is famous for music knowledge in Australia.  The game features 4,000 music trivia questions covering a period of five decades.

Name: Our Great Game
Description:
Our Great Game is a board game which simulates the game of Australian Rules Football.

The game was probably first published in the 1920s by the National Game Company. Several versions exist. Two versions are produced on a thick backing either 36cm x 36cm or 48 x 31cm. Common to all versions is the wording 'Our Great Game' on the inside board.  The box or board covers have various titles, including 'The National Football game', 'Our Great Game' or 'The Game of Football'. All but one version has the playing field angled across the board. Later copies were printed on thin card, boxed with the logo (but not on the board), including those published by Westley games.

As with the real form of the sport scores are kept for two teams (Yellow and Red team in the game) and 4 quarters are played with the duration decided by the players. The scores are 6 points for a goal (through the tall posts) and 1 point for a behind (number 31 in the game). Play starts by the sum of two dice. A disc (ball) is placed at that players feet that corresponds to the number. (i.e If 6 and 2 are rolled, player 8 Red team has the ball) If the player is in the defensive zone (closer half of their opponents goal) the next roll of the dice must be subtracted (i.e If player 8 (Red Team) rolls a 1 the next player to receive the ball is 8 - 1 = 7. If the red team is still in possession they keep rolling the dice but if the number turns it over to the yellow team then its their roll of the dice. When the player is forward of their center line, then they are deemed to be in attack. In this case instead of subtracting the dice roll they must add. (i.e Player 7 (Red Team) is forward of center so they roll say a 3 - the next player to receive the ball is 10 (7 + 3). Movement and scoring is done in this way. If a behind is scored the ball is placed on player 29 of the opposing team to kick out. The highest score after 4 quarters is the winner.

Name: Ever-Victorious Armies: Fast Play Rules Nineteenth Century Warfare, c. 1790 to c. 1885
Description:
Light, quick skirmish game of warfare during the 19th Century.

From the Introduction

The late nineteenth-century has always been a popular subject for wargaming, and there are already plenty of rule sets around.  But when HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company) was planning their Victorian British in Home Service uniforms figure range they decided to publish their own rules to go with them.  Why?

Firstly, because the emphasis in Ever-Victorious Armies is rather different from that of most rule sets.  The authors were especially interested in the role which the British army might have played in a European War of the period, and so they wanted to cater for this sort of hypothetical scenario. They also wanted to be able to fight "alternative history" campaigns, involving fictional armies based fairly loosely on real-life prototypes.  This required a "broad brush" approach, catching the essence of the period, but without concentrating too intently on the tactical and organizational minutiae of a particular conflict.

The other factor which HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company) sought to emphasize in this war-game is the "game" part.  Some of the best known rules for the period -- as for many other periods -- are a bit too much like work to play.  Authenticity is all very nice but real warfare has been aptly described as a combination of ninety percent boredom and ten percent confusion.  HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company) have tried not to reproduce this aspect too faithfully in Ever-Victorious Armies.

Ever-Victorious Armies is based on individual figures, which are removed to simulate casualties, thus minimizing record-keeping.  It requires little if any paperwork, no little boxes to tick off, and only one kind of dice.  The command and control rules require each on-table unit to be given orders at the start of the game, to which they must try to adhere as long as morale test results permit. The orders should specify the objective and route if the units are to move, or the position to be defended if not. An army's Commander-in-Cheif may attempt to modify the orders of one unit, per turn, by utilizing a messenger figure to convey a new set of written orders.

The rules ideally require figures to be based so that they are individually removable, but multi-figure "blocks" -- like those produced in 2mm and 6mm bi Irregular Miniatures -- can be used instead, if you prefer to use the smaller scales.  In this case, simply treat each block as if it was a figure.

A game involving several hundred figures a side can easily be completed in an evening. After a few attempts players will be able to remember most of the rules which are needed, and so will be able to keep the game moving without constantly referring to the rulebook.  This leaves the players free to enjoy the games and admire their carefully painted figures -- which is what it is all about, after all.

Name: Soldiers of the Dragon
Description:
From the original Avalanche Press 2007 newsletter announcement:

Soldiers of the Dragon:  Rob Markham takes Avalanche Press' popular Soldier system to the Chinese civil war that raged from 936 to 951 AD. Two to five players lead Chinese kingdoms trying to unify all of the Middle Kingdom. Units represent armies of infantry, cavalry or elephants, and fleets of warships. One map, 120 decadently thick tiles, 88 over-sized playing pieces.

Name: Get the Gem
Description:
Get the Gem is a hide-and-seek game that comes to life with your child's imagination. One player creates a trail of arrows past make-believe obstacles like rushing rivers, fallen logs, and boiling mud. The other players follow that path and act out an adventure on their way to hidden treasure.

Includes an alternative, counting-game version.

Name: The Farmers Market
Description:
We are customers visiting the market. Sometimes we buy things. Sometimes we just look. Sometimes we return stuff. It's up to us to decide what to buy or just look at. Each vendor must sell enough to be able to come back another day. If they don't make some money or even lose money, they will leave.

So, the object is to watch out for everyone's welfare. To do this well, we must discuss, plan, & problem-solve together, so everyone will enjoy some success. Lots of decision making for each player. The basic game plays quickly, with an advanced game for older players.

Name: Boer en Rooinekspel
Description:
A Dutch board game produced at the time of the Anglo-Boer War.
One player represents the Boers (literally "farmers", the name then used for people of Dutch descent in Southern Africa). The other player the British. The players roll and move their pawns around the board. The Boers have to arrive in Cape Town, while the British have to arrive in Pretoria. 
The first player to arrive at their destination wins the game.

Name: Sexyonary
Description:
Very similar to Pictionary but with a sex theme.
Players take a card and then draw the concept of the category that matches the one on the board. When someone guesses the correct answer they roll a dice and move to another spot. 
The game ends when one teams reaches the final spot and wins.

Name: Lilli muistipeli
Description: Lilli muistipeli is a simple children's memory game. The theme is from the TV show "Fifi and the Flowertots" ("Lilli ja kukkaisystävät" in Finnish). Each player gets a player board and tries to collect the series of six pictures on her board. The game is played as a usual memory game.

Name: Maatilakierros
Description:
Maatilakierros is a simple children's game where players move around the farm by rolling the dice. The dice is not numbered but instead has different colors on its side. On blue, green, yellow and orange you get to move to the next circle with the appropriate color, on red you move backwards and on white you do not move at all. The winner is the player who reaches the last circle first.

The components are nice - the dice is big, as is the board which is constructed from over 30 pieces. Soft and cute animals (a cat, a dog, a pig and a cow) are used as player tokens.

Name: The Great Riverboat Race
Description: A simple dice game similar to other Channel Craft and is a part of the Vintage Game Series. The game comes in a tin box with the rules printed on the lid. It includes 2 pegs, one dice, a playing platform and instructions. The game is also called "The Great Race".

Name: Insite: The Party Game of Predicting the Future
Description: Insite is a unique concept in games because it opens up the universe inside your own mind.  Includes manual, board and cards.  Appears to be somewhat similar to tarot cards.

Name: Alemannen-Skat
Description:
In Alemannen-Skat, played with a 7 through ace from a standard deck of cards, the two players simultaneously each select a card from their hand, then reveal it; then they do that again.  Next, the highest card "grabs" the second-highest card, and the lowest card "grabs" the second-lowest card.  The players now place their winnings on one of three fields they have, color-coded like a traffic light:


     green: the value of the cards on it are multiplied by +2
     yellow: the value of the cards on it are multiplied by +1
     red: the value of the cards on it are multiplied by -1


The cards and suits all have specific relative values, so every card can be ranked uniquely, and some card score more than others.  Additionally, the positive discard fields have a limit of how many of the 32 cards in the deck they can receive.

Published in spielbox Number 4 of 2007.

Name: 3.. 2.. 1.. meins!
Description: Players bid for goods cards, trying to collect a set of 3 cards with one common characteristic: card color, goods type, or age of goods. Losing bidders pay a fee based on the highest denomination in the winning bid. Players can extend the bidding by playing a blockade chip. Going broke puts you out of the game.

Name: Cranium Jam Pack Jam
Description:
Race to pack the trunk full of silly stuff
Pack a cake, guitar ... even the kitchen sink!
Spring-loaded timer adds suspense
If time runs out -- stuff goes flying!
Second-chance rounds so everyone can shine
The "pack the trunk before it pops!" game

A cactus, recliner, skateboard, birthday cake ... Cranium Jam Pack Jam has you racing the clock to pack the trunk with everything including the kitchen sink! Hurry -- if the timer goes off before you’re finished packing -- Pop! -- the spring-loaded trunk sends your stuff flying!

Can you squeeze in the cactus next to the spare tire, or will only the skateboard fit?

Players draw cards to select the items to pack, then fit them into the trunk of the toy car before the timer goes off. Quick rounds and second chances keep players on their toes. With silly sound effects, pop-out action, and unexpected items to squeeze in, packing the trunk has never been this fun!

What's in the box?
Includes a toy car, 14 packable objects, 32 game cards, score pad, and pencil.

Name: Game of Fox Hunting
Description: Similar to many horse racing games, instead players move around the board chasing a fox.  The board is three-dimensional, with paper buildings and trees.

Name: Safety First
Description: Think of it as the origin of "Frogger."  Players cross streets and get around town while dodging cars and buses.

Name: Fluxx: 10th Anniversary Party Promos – Expansion Card Pack
Description:
Expansion for Fluxx to commemorate the game's 10th Anniversary.  The name is a bit misleading, because this is a 7 card expansion pack, not a promo.  It includes 1 New Rule, 2 Actions, 2 Goals, 1 Keeper, and 1 Creeper.  The Creeper is a new card type originally designed for Zombie Fluxx but first released in this expansion.

Part of the Fluxx series.

Name: Keys to the Kingdom
Description: Keys to the Kingdom is a boardgame that attempts to simulate the Christian life.  The players roll the dice and move through 5 concentric bands.  In order to progress, one must collect key cards, which represent faith, truth, and humility.  Once all of these are collected, it is possible to move into the inner rings.  However, once you have reached the inner rings, it is possible to help those who are stuck.  You may give up your turn, in order to give one of your key cards to someone in need.  For this kind deed, you receive a crown card.  There are also a number of obstacles, including pride, doubt, deception, and the sins of flesh.  Along the way, one may also need to draw a Scripture card.  These include a Bible verse that you need to memorize before its your turn again in order to proceed.  The game ends once a player reaches the center or when a timer goes off (the rapture option).  The winner is the player with the most crown cards.  Thus, victory goes to the player who helped the most other players.

Name: Walt Disney's Uncle Scrooge Lost Money Game
Description:
This game appears to be a typical children's Spin and move game with the object being to collect all the "lost" gold and return it to the center.
According to the box the contents are:
16 playing pieces (colored plastic cups in 4 colors)
spinner (for movement)
Gameboard
Winner card
Though its not listed I'm assuming that instructions of some kind are included (though my copy is missing so maybe not)

Name: Monopoly: Option One Mortgage Corporation
Description:
This is an official limited edition version of Monopoly which is themed on the Option One Mortgage Company.  The tokens, board spaces, cards, etc. are themed on various aspects of the company and the mortgage industry.


According to amazon.com:
"This game was manufactured in 2000 and there were 5000 issues printed. The Manager of Custom Game Developement at USAopoly states, "This was a custom game not offered to the public and all 5000 copies were gifts."

Name: Go Goddess Girl! Tween Talk
Description:
Go Goddess Girl Tween Talk empowers girls to share their feelings, to say what's on their minds and in their heart. From the publisher: "The goal of the game is easy and fun you  answer questions all about tween life,( the stuff you love to talk about anyway), and build your own Go Goddess Girl bracelet. but stay cool, there are no right or wrong answers."

Includes: 210 purple power beads, Goddess Girl guide, 7 decks of cards, Tray with spinner, Game rules, Elastic thread

Name: Rock and Roll Word Game
Description: This word game uses plastic dice with letters and scores,with some faces of the dice having a musical note on them. The game is similar to a "Scribbage" type game, where players attempt to make words and phrases from the letters that are rolled--this game uses a variant with a punning musical theme.

Name: My Dog Has Fleas
Description: This game has a large plastic dog with small holes in its back.  Players each have a set of colored plastic "flea" pieces with pegs on them.  Players compete to see who can be the first to place and keep all of their fleas on the dog.  When its tail is pushed down, it randomly pushes some of them out, making it a challenge to keep them on it.

Name: Big Bubba's Redneck Trivia Game
Description:
This is a party-style trivia game with questions themed on the "redneck" culture of the southern U.S.

From the publisher: "Get your friends and family together. It’s time to challenge them to an evening of fun, learning and reminiscing. Bubba has been bear hunting in Canada and is on his way to Darlington for the race. By answering right and betting smart, you can beat Bubba and your friends at this most unique and entertaining board game. Over 20 categories, 400 questions, authentic shotgun shell game pieces, 50 go-fishing cards, Bubba bucks for betting , and the funniest game board anywhere."

Name: Pilgrim: A Game of Christian Challenge and Progress
Description:
Pilgrim: A Game of Christian Challenge and Progress is a Christian-themed religious game that uses mechanics something like recent party games like "Cranium."  Players move on a board, and depending on where they land, they might have to do one of various activities such as: perform a charade, sing a verse of a (religious) song or chorus, give a testimony, answer multiple choice questions, do a word challenges, answer true or false questions, or do a bible character identification.

Game includes 600 Cards (100 in each color: Red, Yellow, Blue, Purple, Green and White); 6 Colored Pawns; 140 Coin Cards (for moving or navigating on the board); One Minute Timer; Gameboard; and Game Rules

Name: The Ginger Meggs Paper Chase Game
Description: A roll and move type game using the theme of Ginger Meggs, who is a famous cartoon boy in a long-running comic strip in Australia.  Players compete to accomplish objectives on the board while avoiding challenges like bullies.

Name: Superman: Search for Superman's Deadliest Enemies
Description: A spin and move game which has players competing to locate and then beat some of Superman's most famous opponents.

Name: The Hunting Dogs
Description: This is a game similar to Hungry, Hungry Hippos,although it is for only two players.  Each player pushes a lever which moves the head of a plastic hound dog.  The two dogs are at the end of a small playing field which holds rolling marbles.  The winner is the player whose dog captured the most marbles.

Name: Lincoln On Board
Description: Lincoln On Board is a Monopoly style game where the property and other spaces represent businesses and landmarks in the city of Lincoln, Nebraska (USA).

Name: Spritz & Tooor
Description: He shoots, he scores! Squirt and Goal from Haba® is the ultimate in water soccer! Use the Penguin and Frog to squirt water onto the soccer ball to score goals - what fun! Perfect for the pool! Includes a ring "field" with two goals, ball and squirters. For ages 4 and above

Name: Reiter and Tercio
Description:
Reiter and Tercio is a simple card driven wargame with a Pike & Shot Theme. It simulates a 16-17th Century Battlefield. Each figure represents a company or unit of men. Win by capturing your opponent’s Field Commander or Camp. Rules for different troop and terrain types. A free copy of the rules can be found at: 
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/RAT.html

Name: Shenandoah Management Games for Supervisors
Description:
This business game published by McGraw Hill puts a single player or two teams of players in charge of the "lifelike" Shenandoah Guitar Company.  There are nine separate games included that are designed to teach management skills. After these lessons, you should be able to "apply, analyze, synthesize, and evaluate your learning experience" and be ready to run a real company. The nine games included are:

1. Supervisory Performance Challenge
2. Extending the Yield
3. Energy Patrol
4. Handling the Grievance
5. Solving the Variance Problem
6. Managing Your In Basket
7. Mapping the Mandolin
8. Bridging the Quality Gap
9. Facing the Music

Name: The Vault
Description: This game is based on the British television game show, "The Vault."  Players compete to correctly guess/identify the combination to the vault in order to be the winner, including through answering a series of trivia questions.

Name: Jive Bunny's Chart Challenge
Description: Jive Bunny's Chart Challenge is a game using the themed cartoon character of "Jive Bunny."  Players compete in the music industry for the success of their career, with the winner the one who makes it to the top of the charts.

Name: Stringfellows: The Board Game
Description:
You & your friends have been invited for a night out with Peter Stringfellow.  The race is on to look your best.  There are 2 sets of cards - 1 with trivia questions you must answer and the other with items you must collect to ensure you look your best for your big night out!
 The 1st game involves getting yourself ready to go out - visits to the hairdressers, beauty salon and clothes shops.  Where you go for your preparations decides how good you will look for your night out - obviously you would rather go to a designer hairdresser than the "Pudding Basin" salon - likewise "last weeks socks" are not as desirable as "straight off the catwalk"!
 You travel around the board trying to pamper an primp yourself for your big night out.  This game ends and is won by the person who achieves the highest value of collected items.
 The second game takes place inside Peter Stringfellows' Club.  The object is to try and get next to your favourite star who is in the nightclub.  But be warned - there are many pitfalls!  You need to work your way past the stars, personal assistants and bodyguards or minders and your knowledge of celebrity trivia, drinks, dancing and music will be put to the test!
 The game ends when all the celebrity counters have been collected off the board - the person with the most celebrities around them is the winner!

This is a game intended for adults (suggested age is 18 and over)

Name: Game of Yachting
Description: A small roll-and-move (or in this case spin) game in which advantageous spins cut the size of the sailing course.

Name: The Wild West Game
Description: Simple roll-and-move game featuring scenes from the American West.

Name: Wörter Würfeln
Description:
This is a German word dice game, where the object is to form words from 13 dice with letters on them. Each player simply rolls the dice, turns the sand timer over and tries to use each die in forming a word or separate words. The letters have values and at the end of one's turn, the player scores for letters in words formed and subtracts the value of unused letters. Two of the dice have a blank face (although the rules mention only one) which are treated as Jokers, which can be used to represent any letter. 
A variant described in the rules allows words to be formed crossword style and letters that are part of a word vertically and horizontally count double. 
Recommended Ages 8 and up

Name: Host Your Own Quiz Night: Trivia Team Challenge
Description: Fairly straightforward trivia game designed to be played with two teams of players and one person acting as the "host" of the game.  Trivia questions are separated into various categories from which players choose.

Name: Motor Rally Formula One
Description: This is a basic roll and move game where players compete to race on a hexagonally shaped track by rolling the dice and dealing with the traffic icons/rules they encounter.

Name: Today's The Day
Description: This is a trivia game based on the popular UK tv show.  The game consists of 366 question cards which correspond to trivia questions for every day of the year.

Name: Monopoly: Santiago, Chile
Description: This is a Monopoly game using Santiago’s streets, Chile. The game uses pesos with Chilean money pictures instead of dollars.

Name: Victory at Sea: Age of Dreadnoughts
Description: Based on the Victory at Sea: World War II Naval Combat Game WWII game (core game design by Matthew Sprange) Age of Dreadnoughts is an all new set of rules and fleet lists for pre-dreadnought and WWI naval combat. Besides basic fire and movement rules formation fighting, destroyer flotillas, and even poor compartmentalization are detailed as well as other other rules simulating naval combat at the beginning of the 20th century.

Name: Eurooppa-peli
Description:
Eurooppa-peli [Finnish for "The Europe-Game"] is an educational party game. It combines a simple roll-and-move mechanic with trivia. Players move their pawns around a map depicting the 2006 member states of the European Union. After each move the players answer questions arranged in five broad topics: A) The EU; B) sport; C) history & geography; D) art, science and technology; and E) society, nature & culture. For a correct answer the player receives an EU-flag within that topic. After collecting ten flags (two flags of each topic A-E) the player heads for goal and wins the game.

This seems a very simple game that has its primary purpose in teaching matters concerning the EU with European history and culture. The components of the game are nice and look professional enough, but there is very little to call a design here.

Name: Oil Field
Description:
In Oil Field, players act as rivaling energy companies. They try to reach the newly built oil field first and thus get the lucrative deal with the oil company and win the game.

First players shuffle their land card decks and build a map for the game. Each player has identical 31 land cards and together they form a 21x3 (for two players) or 14x9 (for four players) map. In the middle of the playing area is the oil field that players try to reach. The land cards have two playable sides and they have different rocks/obstacles in them so basically each player faces equally difficult landscape which to overcome.

Now players start to build their oil pipes. On their way to the oil field they need to turn the land cards to make the route possible, flip land cards around to hopefully reveal more suitable obstacles or switch land cards with adjacent ones.

Many land cards have some specialties. Yellow-edged has to be turned around once player builds a pipe next to it, some give extra action and some force player to flip surrounding cards around.

				
				
					Online Play
    http://www.tuonelaproductions.com/index.php?page_id=13

Name: Musaraña
Description:
This is a Charades kind game. Team A picks a card in the category shown on the board and gives it to team B. Team B reads the theme and writes a word for that theme. Then it shows it to the member of team A that will do the charade.

The categories are:

     T.V.
     Movies
     Sports
     Literature
     Culture
     Characters
     Music
     Geography
     Miscellaneous
